summary:
Tony: I got a call from Peter's school saying that he was immature.
Steve: I mean, they've got a point. Remember when he got...
body:
Tony: I got a call from Peter’s school saying that he was immature.

Steve: I mean, they’ve got a point. Remember when he got excited because he could drink two capri suns at once?

Peter, walking in with three capri suns: Dads, you’re not gonna believe this!

reblog.comment:
Tony: I got a call from Peter’s school saying that he was immature.

Steve: I mean, they’ve got a point. Remember when he got excited because he could drink two capri suns at once?

Peter, walking in with three capri suns: Dads, you’re not gonna believe this!

trail.content_raw:
Tony: I got a call from Peter’s school saying that he was immature.

Steve: I mean, they’ve got a point. Remember when he got excited because he could drink two capri suns at once?

Peter, walking in with three capri suns: Dads, you’re not gonna believe this!

Steve: I mean, they’ve got a point. Remember when he got excited because he could drink two capri suns at once?

Peter, walking in with three capri suns: Dads, you’re not gonna believe this!

summary: hostage - Chapter 1 - SaintDracTheAlien - Marvel Cinematic Universe [Archive of Our Own]
title: hostage - Chapter 1 - SaintDracTheAlien - Marvel Cinematic Universe [Archive of Our Own]
excerpt: An Archive of Our Own, a project of the Organization for Transformative Works
description:
Chapters: 3/?
Fandom: Marvel Cinematic Universe, The Avengers (Marvel Movies), Marvel
Rating: Teen And Up Audiences
Warnings: Graphic Depictions Of Violence
Relationships: Wanda Maximoff/Vision
Characters: Wanda Maximoff, Vision (Marvel)
Additional Tags: I’ll add tags when the story is completed, for now this is just for ocean eyes readers :)
Series: Part 2 of the road to scarletvision: from ultron to civil war, from strangers to something more
Summary:

SEQUEL TO “OCEAN EYES” - PART TWO OF TWO

As Ultron’s terror ends, new challenges begin for the Avengers’ two newest members. Wanda begins her time with the team as an isolated and grieving sister, while Vision discovers that becoming an Avenger will be more difficult than expected. An intertwined origin story, along with shared loneliness and uncertainty about their new lives, will eventually bring the two heroes together into the duo we already know and love.

A post-Ultron story intended to give Wanda Maximoff and Vision some new character and relationship development between canonical installments.

summary: Marvel Action: Spider-Man #1 | GTMedia: Garbage Tier Media Entertainment Reviews & Troll Pieces blog
title: Marvel Action: Spider-Man #1 | GTMedia: Garbage Tier Media Entertainment Reviews & Troll Pieces blog
excerpt: • Delilah S. Dawson (Author) • Fico Ossio (Pencils,Cover)• Kevin Eastman (Variant) • Ronda Pattison (Colorist) I haven't purchased a Spider-man comic in a few y
description:
The characters are all pretty much what you expect them to be. If this was my first comic I wouldn’t be terribly disappointed. The idea of Tony Stark possibly playing mentor to these characters did sort of rub me the wrong way though.

The art direction is very fluid and energetic with Ronda Pattison’s colors being the MVP for the issue especially when Spiderman is in costume and doing his thing.

reblog.comment:

title: Wailing
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2BLUTNZ

by Lone_Wolf_Fanfics

Ryan is the unofficial Winchester sister to both Sam and Dean. Born a banshee she has struggled for years to control and predict her powers.

Now as the trio take some time to rest in New York, Ryan’s banshee powers draw her towards an attempted murder that lands her right in the path of the Avengers and unknowingly her biological father.

Words: 4161, Chapters: 4/?, Language: English

Series: Part 10 of Supernatural/Marvel Crossovers

  • Fandoms: Supernatural, Marvel Cinematic Universe, The Avengers (Marvel Movies)
  • Rating: Teen And Up Audiences
  • Warnings: No Archive Warnings Apply
  • Categories: F/M
  • Characters: Dean Winchester, Sam Winchester, Original Supernatural (TV) Character(s), James “Bucky” Barnes, Clint Barton, Natasha Romanov (Marvel), Steve Rogers, Tony Stark, Castiel (Supernatural), Bruce Banner, Nick Fury
  • Relationships: Steve Rogers/Original Female Character(s), Steve Rogers/Original Character(s), Dean Winchester & Original Female Character(s), Sam Winchester & Original Female Character(s)
  • Additional Tags: Banshees, Banshee Powers

blog.name: ao3feed-tonystark
blog.title: Ao3-Feed: Tony Stark
blog.description: This blog is an automated list of the stories posted on Archive Of Our Own under the Tony Stark tag. The stories are automatically posted here from the AO3 RSS feed.

title: Choosing You
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2zBKkf0

by angelxtal

When James Barnes wakes up from Chryo, he has to find out who he is and what’s important to him. He learns that freedom is the ability to make your own decisions. Steve never let him choose what he wanted to do–he rushed into battle against the man whose parents Bucky killed and gave Bucky no chance to decide for himself that he wanted to take responsibility for his actions as the Winter Soldier.

But Tony Stark, the man who invited James into his home, always lets James choose for himself.

Words: 4568, Chapters: 1/?, Language: English

Series: Part 6 of MCU Stories

  • Fandoms: Captain America - All Media Types, Iron Man (Movies), The Avengers (Marvel) - All Media Types
  • Rating: Teen And Up Audiences
  • Warnings: No Archive Warnings Apply
  • Categories: M/M
  • Characters: James “Bucky” Barnes, Tony Stark, Steve Rogers, T'Challa (Marvel), James “Rhodey” Rhodes, Peter Parker, Nakia (Black Panther), Shuri (Marvel)
  • Relationships: James “Bucky” Barnes & Steve Rogers, James “Bucky” Barnes/Tony Stark, Peter Parker & Tony Stark, Pepper Potts & Tony Stark, James “Bucky” Barnes & Peter Parker, Nakia (Black Panther)/T'Challa
  • Additional Tags: Not Steve Rogers Friendly, Slow Burn, Getting Together, Depression, Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder - PTSD, Emotional Hurt/Comfort, Recovery, Falling In Love, Enemies to Friends to Lovers, Figuring Things Out, Revelations, Protective Peter Parker

A post shared by Opus De' (@mbrella_sound_radio) on Dec 2, 2018 at 9:33am PST

tags: sorry for the tag spam im just sorta prouf of this
body:
Superhero support group

Bucky Barnes accidentally starting a support group for heroes manipulated into doing evil.

It starts out as just him and Natasha, talking quietly about what they were trained to do. They try to remember as much as they can, each mission, each target. They encourage each other when it gets difficult to talk about. Sometimes there are just long periods of silence, both of them wrapped up in their own memories and feelings of guilt that plague them still, even now. But it helps to know that they aren’t alone.

Then one day, Wanda walks in on the two of them sitting silently together. She doesn’t have to ask what they are doing, or why; the guilt haunts her too. Bucky looks at her, and at the seat next to them, and she understands that it is an invitation. She sits down, hesitantly, and thinks about losing control, what that does to people. Here she was with people that knew what that felt like. She thinks, and she begins to feel ever so slightly better.

As time goes by, more people begin to join the group. When Clint finds them, he turns to Bucky. He wants to talk about the Tesseract, how it felt like his sight was being filtered and, hearing aids or not, he couldn’t hear anything but the words of Loki ringing in his ears, and how his mind was being delicately dismantled and rebuilt for an entirely different cause. Bucky nods, and Clint speaks. And he feels relief, because although it was years ago, he’s never quite been able to shake the feeling that he was somehow at fault. He brings Erik Selvig the next time he comes. Heroes don’t always have superpowers.

Tony knocks on the door of the room they sit in a few months later. He isn’t entirely sure whether they’ll want him, but Bucky tells him that everyone is there to listen, not to pass judgement. So Tony sits down, and begins to talk about Ultron. It’s hard, really hard, after internalizing the blame for all this time. It takes a few sessions, but he manages, and he is reassured that he isn’t at fault for being under the Mind Stone’s control. It isn’t the whole battle, but he leaves each time feeling that at least some progress has been made.

Jane Foster appears now and again, when she’s not working. She talks about the Aether, because whilst its presence may have protected her, she wonders how long she could have gone on for with its power occupying her veins, eating her from the inside. She wonders out loud about the harm she could have caused, and the regret she feels for not recognising the threat sooner. They tell her that no-one knows everything, and that what she did is enough. She knows this already, but hearing it from other voices is comforting. She leaves each meeting with a new source of strength, resolving to work harder and blame herself less.

Steve drops in once or twice, feeling somewhat uncomfortable, for his problem seemed so much lesser than that of the others here. He talks nevertheless, because aren’t words the greatest weapon? He doesn’t want to be the symbol of an America that he doesn’t believe in, that he opposes with every fibre of his being. Everything he stands for has been warped and twisted, taken as theirs by people he would gladly hurt if he ever got the chance, and he doesn’t know if he can fix it. He’s not even sure of his own identity anymore. He is told that he is so much more than his suit and shield, and he is determined to keep fighting. Anyone who tries to change what he truly stands for will have to face him and everything he will always be.

But the most surprising addition to the group comes unexpectedly. Bucky walks into what he assumes is an empty room, set up for their meeting, and sees a figure in green sitting on the sofa. The figure turns, and Bucky is staring at Loki. Before he can react, Loki’s hands are raised in surrender, and he tells Bucky very quietly that he doesn’t have anyone else to talk to. So Bucky sits, and listens to him talk about the Tesseract and Thanos and the constant fear and hunger and guilt he lives with every single day, and he softens. When the others come in, they are understandably shocked, and some move to attack, but Bucky tells them in no uncertain terms that Loki is welcome, just as they all were. It takes a while, but the more he talks, the more the suspicion wears away. Some of his old prejudice against humans still lingers, but it ebbs a little more every time he leaves the group feeling that little bit safer.

Sam joins the group for each of their sessions. He may not be able to relate to their stories, but he listens, and he offers advice where he can. He’s been a part of enough support groups to know what it feels like to share your own story. Bruce wanders in sometimes, because however much he protests that he isn’t that kind of doctor, he knows that it’s important that these people get heard. It reminds him why they need to keep fighting. For a world where this can never happen again.

They grow and grow, these once-hurting, slowly-healing people. More and more people find them, get better, stay and help others. They will change the world, even if it only starts small. Bucky smiles sometimes, watching these people, looking over what he has helped to create. He thinks that the feeling swelling in his chest might just be pride.

Bonus content:

The Guardians hear about the group (probably through Thor, who is incredibly proud of his brother and will talk about the change in him to anyone who stands still long enough). Shortly afterwards, there’s a similar group established among them. Peter, Gamora, Yondu, Mantis and very occasionally Rocket go out to whatever bar is closest, and whilst it takes them a few drinks most of the time, they talk about Ego and Thanos and Rocket’s creators and how they can fix things, but mostly they understand each other’s hurt. Gamora reaches out to Nebula, and the next time they go, she is waiting for them at the bar. Although she never says it, it does help her, finally, to feel like she has a family again. The next time Gamora hugs her, she hugs her tightly back.

Steve drops in once or twice, feeling somewhat uncomfortable, for his problem seemed so much lesser than that of the others here. He talks nevertheless, because aren’t words the greatest weapon? He doesn’t want to be the symbol of an America that he doesn’t believe in, that he opposes with every fibre of his being. Everything he stands for has been warped and twisted, taken as theirs by people he would gladly hurt if he ever got the chance, and he doesn’t know if he can fix it. He’s not even sure of his own identity anymore. He is told that he is so much more than his suit and shield, and he is determined to keep fighting. Anyone who tries to change what he truly stands for will have to face him and everything he will always be.

But the most surprising addition to the group comes unexpectedly. Bucky walks into what he assumes is an empty room, set up for their meeting, and sees a figure in green sitting on the sofa. The figure turns, and Bucky is staring at Loki. Before he can react, Loki’s hands are raised in surrender, and he tells Bucky very quietly that he doesn’t have anyone else to talk to. So Bucky sits, and listens to him talk about the Tesseract and Thanos and the constant fear and hunger and guilt he lives with every single day, and he softens. When the others come in, they are understandably shocked, and some move to attack, but Bucky tells them in no uncertain terms that Loki is welcome, just as they all were. It takes a while, but the more he talks, the more the suspicion wears away. Some of his old prejudice against humans still lingers, but it ebbs a little more every time he leaves the group feeling that little bit safer.

Sam joins the group for each of their sessions. He may not be able to relate to their stories, but he listens, and he offers advice where he can. He’s been a part of enough support groups to know what it feels like to share your own story. Bruce wanders in sometimes, because however much he protests that he isn’t that kind of doctor, he knows that it’s important that these people get heard. It reminds him why they need to keep fighting. For a world where this can never happen again.

They grow and grow, these once-hurting, slowly-healing people. More and more people find them, get better, stay and help others. They will change the world, even if it only starts small. Bucky smiles sometimes, watching these people, looking over what he has helped to create. He thinks that the feeling swelling in his chest might just be pride.

Bonus content:

The Guardians hear about the group (probably through Thor, who is incredibly proud of his brother and will talk about the change in him to anyone who stands still long enough). Shortly afterwards, there’s a similar group established among them. Peter, Gamora, Yondu, Mantis and very occasionally Rocket go out to whatever bar is closest, and whilst it takes them a few drinks most of the time, they talk about Ego and Thanos and Rocket’s creators and how they can fix things, but mostly they understand each other’s hurt. Gamora reaches out to Nebula, and the next time they go, she is waiting for them at the bar. Although she never says it, it does help her, finally, to feel like she has a family again. The next time Gamora hugs her, she hugs her tightly back.

trail.content_raw:
Superhero support group

Bucky Barnes accidentally starting a support group for heroes manipulated into doing evil.

It starts out as just him and Natasha, talking quietly about what they were trained to do. They try to remember as much as they can, each mission, each target. They encourage each other when it gets difficult to talk about. Sometimes there are just long periods of silence, both of them wrapped up in their own memories and feelings of guilt that plague them still, even now. But it helps to know that they aren’t alone.

Then one day, Wanda walks in on the two of them sitting silently together. She doesn’t have to ask what they are doing, or why; the guilt haunts her too. Bucky looks at her, and at the seat next to them, and she understands that it is an invitation. She sits down, hesitantly, and thinks about losing control, what that does to people. Here she was with people that knew what that felt like. She thinks, and she begins to feel ever so slightly better.

As time goes by, more people begin to join the group. When Clint finds them, he turns to Bucky. He wants to talk about the Tesseract, how it felt like his sight was being filtered and, hearing aids or not, he couldn’t hear anything but the words of Loki ringing in his ears, and how his mind was being delicately dismantled and rebuilt for an entirely different cause. Bucky nods, and Clint speaks. And he feels relief, because although it was years ago, he’s never quite been able to shake the feeling that he was somehow at fault. He brings Erik Selvig the next time he comes. Heroes don’t always have superpowers.

Tony knocks on the door of the room they sit in a few months later. He isn’t entirely sure whether they’ll want him, but Bucky tells him that everyone is there to listen, not to pass judgement. So Tony sits down, and begins to talk about Ultron. It’s hard, really hard, after internalizing the blame for all this time. It takes a few sessions, but he manages, and he is reassured that he isn’t at fault for being under the Mind Stone’s control. It isn’t the whole battle, but he leaves each time feeling that at least some progress has been made.

Jane Foster appears now and again, when she’s not working. She talks about the Aether, because whilst its presence may have protected her, she wonders how long she could have gone on for with its power occupying her veins, eating her from the inside. She wonders out loud about the harm she could have caused, and the regret she feels for not recognising the threat sooner. They tell her that no-one knows everything, and that what she did is enough. She knows this already, but hearing it from other voices is comforting. She leaves each meeting with a new source of strength, resolving to work harder and blame herself less.

Steve drops in once or twice, feeling somewhat uncomfortable, for his problem seemed so much lesser than that of the others here. He talks nevertheless, because aren’t words the greatest weapon? He doesn’t want to be the symbol of an America that he doesn’t believe in, that he opposes with every fibre of his being. Everything he stands for has been warped and twisted, taken as theirs by people he would gladly hurt if he ever got the chance, and he doesn’t know if he can fix it. He’s not even sure of his own identity anymore. He is told that he is so much more than his suit and shield, and he is determined to keep fighting. Anyone who tries to change what he truly stands for will have to face him and everything he will always be.

But the most surprising addition to the group comes unexpectedly. Bucky walks into what he assumes is an empty room, set up for their meeting, and sees a figure in green sitting on the sofa. The figure turns, and Bucky is staring at Loki. Before he can react, Loki’s hands are raised in surrender, and he tells Bucky very quietly that he doesn’t have anyone else to talk to. So Bucky sits, and listens to him talk about the Tesseract and Thanos and the constant fear and hunger and guilt he lives with every single day, and he softens. When the others come in, they are understandably shocked, and some move to attack, but Bucky tells them in no uncertain terms that Loki is welcome, just as they all were. It takes a while, but the more he talks, the more the suspicion wears away. Some of his old prejudice against humans still lingers, but it ebbs a little more every time he leaves the group feeling that little bit safer.

Sam joins the group for each of their sessions. He may not be able to relate to their stories, but he listens, and he offers advice where he can. He’s been a part of enough support groups to know what it feels like to share your own story. Bruce wanders in sometimes, because however much he protests that he isn’t that kind of doctor, he knows that it’s important that these people get heard. It reminds him why they need to keep fighting. For a world where this can never happen again.

They grow and grow, these once-hurting, slowly-healing people. More and more people find them, get better, stay and help others. They will change the world, even if it only starts small. Bucky smiles sometimes, watching these people, looking over what he has helped to create. He thinks that the feeling swelling in his chest might just be pride.

Bonus content:

The Guardians hear about the group (probably through Thor, who is incredibly proud of his brother and will talk about the change in him to anyone who stands still long enough). Shortly afterwards, there’s a similar group established among them. Peter, Gamora, Yondu, Mantis and very occasionally Rocket go out to whatever bar is closest, and whilst it takes them a few drinks most of the time, they talk about Ego and Thanos and Rocket’s creators and how they can fix things, but mostly they understand each other’s hurt. Gamora reaches out to Nebula, and the next time they go, she is waiting for them at the bar. Although she never says it, it does help her, finally, to feel like she has a family again. The next time Gamora hugs her, she hugs her tightly back.

summary: Can I get a ship with a guy? For the MCU,Marauders and X-Men (if you can) fandoms? I'm Latina, curly hair, brown eyes, a little...
question: Can I get a ship with a guy? For the MCU,Marauders and X-Men (if you can) fandoms? I'm Latina, curly hair, brown eyes, a little bit curvy and thicc. I love laugh n my jokes are bad, I'm funny tho and caring. I'm bubbly if you know me well. I like help people n animals, I'm very impatient and restless, my humor tend to change quick, but in my perspective I'm chill. I love sing but I do it badly, dance and draw,do sports, hang out with my friends and jam out to music that I like.
answer:
Sure, thank you! 


I ship you with Clint, James and Quicksilver!

blog.name: marvelman90
blog.title: Comics That I've Read
blog.description: I read a lot of comics everyday and I wanted to share what I read with you. I have read Marvel comics published 1961 to 1991 (where I am currently reading) Since I will start from where I currently am, there WILL BE SPOILERS from previous comics. I will...

summary:
Fantastic Four #371  The Watcher called Aron had kidnapped 
Alicia Masters, but Mr Fantastic and the Thing followed the trail to...
caption:
Fantastic Four #371

The Watcher called Aron had kidnapped Alicia Masters, but Mr Fantastic and the Thing followed the trail to Aron’s base. It was all a trap, where Aron hoped to imprison the FF in an artificial universe.

Meanwhile, the Power-Skrull, Devos and Lyla (the Human Torch’s Skrull-wife) attacked the Human Torch, almost defeating him. His only choice was to go Nova, which unfortunately caused the Empire State University to burn down.
